My beautiful, brilliant niece after a lot of inner confusion and suffering accepted at 17 that she was transgender.  She told her teachers and classmates, her parents, and received a lot of acceptance and support. But she wasn’t allowed to transition in her dress or sports classes. She saw a psychiatrist.  And in the middle of her senior year, after a very successful school concert, performance, she quietly went into the woods and hung herself.  The school received notification of her designation as a Presidential Scholar two days later.  Everyone was horrified.  Her parents devastated.  We will never truly recover.  I can only wonder, if she’d been allowed to transition in school and find true acceptance with her peers, (she was very popular and a class leader), if the headlines about transgender students were not primarily about not being allowed to use gender appropriate bathrooms, about the murder rates for trans women, about the Republican attacks on transgender medical care, if she’d been able to find a supportive societal context in which to face her personal fears about her identity and the necessity of transitioning, perhaps she would still be with us, and able to contribute her brilliant mind and kindly spirit to solving some of the challenges we face today.  Hate is cheap and lazy. And so very expensive in terms on human potential. And so very ungodly.

I feel like there’s a whole lot of cognitive dissonance in this comment section. 
Firstly we have people who think this is a transwoman. It’s a trans man, which means he was born a girl but underwent hormone replacement therapy to be a man. I don’t particularly care about your opinion on if that makes him a man or not, I just think people need to understand what they’re arguing about, since many clearly don’t. 
That leads us to the second issue, many people think that this trans man shouldn’t be in this women’s competition. There’s two different thought processes. The first is that a trans man is a man, therefore should be in a men’s competition. The second is that a trans man is a girl on steroids therefore shouldn’t be in this competition because of drugs. 
The problem with a lot of people on that first one is because to allow that, they’d have to wonder if they should allow transwomen (male at birth, transitioned to a woman) into women’s sports. That’s the big part of this debate. 
The problem with the second one is that now you’re requiring someone to choose. Either pursue being the person you want to be, in this boy’s case, a man, but be not allowed to contend in something you love, wrestling. Or give up being a man, be miserable, but at least be able to enjoy wrestling. 
That doesn’t seem rightly fair. I understand it’s a nuanced subject, and while I do support trans rights, I also think it’s not as simple as joining whatever group you identify as, because that can ignore physical differences.
But as long as so many of you ignore that trans men are men, and trans women are women, nothing will improve. Once the lot of you accept that these people are valid, maybe then we can work toward figuring out a system that allows them to be who they are without disrupting the careers of both them as well as other athletes that have to work with them.

Some 30 plus years ago, I had started dating a guy, Matt, who was a student at Liberty University.  After a month of getting together and hitting it off, he suddenly disappeared without any further contact.  Eventually, I crossed paths with one of our shared acquaintances, friends and was informed what had happened to Matt.  His roommate had reported him to the LU administrative office for homosexual activity and he was expelled from, or, better put, kicked out of the university.  As part of the process, Matt's parents were called and told of his expulsion, as well as the reason as to why; he was outed to his family.  With his educational aspirations, life being upended, Matt had no other choice, if any, but to return to home in Massachusetts.

I have thought of Matt over the years, wondering how things eventually turned out for him.  Having experienced something, almost, but not quite, similar as a part of an international touring music organization, I can only imagine the embarrassment and shame that he may have felt, but, most of all, put upon him by his family.  

The irony of the matter is the aspect of hypocrisy and, even, revenge to which spurned on the roommate to report Matt to the LU administration.  Unlike Matt, the roommate wasn't as open to being true to his self and living his life.  He had developed feelings for Matt and would show up at the "community" bar located in another city, an hour away from LU.  As made apparent by the shared acquaintance, Matt had rejected his roommate's intimate advances and had decided to moved off campus due to the situation.  The recourse was nothing less than an action of vengeful jealousy and completely hypocritical.

I was the Director of a brand new just opened large,120 children capacity, day care center in 1986. We enrolled an 15mos hemophiliac toddler who had AIDS from a blood transfusion. Other parents weren't told of course, he wore a helmet to protect his head from bumping while learning to walk, but tons of gossip and speculation. Not knowing anything, Parents did not want their child in his class or even on the playground when he was out there. Teachers were told his medical information, his parents agreed to all staff knowing, and they started requesting not working with him or wanting him in same areas as them. The owners as the school had their lawyers look into not allowing him to be enrolled but discovered the parents could sue for discrimination so reluctantly they let me enroll him. It was a horror show for me really, and I supported the family and loved the little plucky guy! They told me about 10 daycare centers who had openings all of a sudden didn't have one after learning about his AIDS.

FACT CHECK- Khelif is not transgender and has never identified as a man. Khelif was born a woman and has identified as such her entire life. She represents a nation where being LGBTQ+ — and attempting to change one’s gender — is outright illegal. 

The basis for the accusations stemmed from a 2023 incident in which Khelif, and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting, were abruptly suspended from the International Boxing Association (IBA) Women’s World Boxing Championships. Both are competing at the Paris games. IBA President Umar Kremlev claimed that genetic testing had proven Khelif “had XY chromosomes,” and was therefore ineligible to compete. The specific tests conducted and their results were never made public, and Khelif challenged the claim. It should be noted that the IBA was stripped of its role in organizing the Olympic games in 2019 amid ongoing corruption allegations, and evidence the organization rigged matches at the 2016 Rio Olympics. 
Certain genetic conditions can result in some women having XY chromosomes with little to no indication in their physical presentation. The same is true for men, who can present the physical characteristics of a male while having XX genotype.

I think this is a bit one sided and out of context, perhaps, for the class this student was taking, and what the professor was attempting to communicate.  That said, no, I also don’t understand the whole multi-gender thing.  But that said, we learn a lot as we grow older:

Example 1:  I was told that a man’s contribution to fertilizing a woman’s egg determined the sex of a child, X or Y, Male/Female.  I later found out that women can have eggs that are predetermined to prefer only male sperm with X or Y chemical surface makeup to fertilize them – therefore, it is not solely up to a man to determine the sex of a child – a woman’s eggs have a say in the matter.

Example 2:  We all learn early on that identical twins are, well, “identical”.  As I grew older, I learned that just as a heart does not break evenly when in love, a cell does not split evenly when creating identical twins – even though two people may look alike.  Also, there are different types of identical twins, “identical”, “identical mirror twins”, etc.

*Shock: Black people abandoning Biden*
Apr 1, 2022  WASHINGTON EXAMINER

*In an otherwise OK review of President Joe Biden, the latest Marquette University poll has revealed a stunning drop in support from black people, the key to Democrats keeping the presidency in 2024.*

The new Marquette University Law School survey found a 32% cratering of black support for Biden, who now enjoys just a 56% approval rating among African Americans, among the worst ever for a modern Democratic president.

By comparison, the same survey less than a year ago found his support among black people at 88%.

The drop was so noticeable that the school mentioned it in their headline on the survey, which put Biden’s overall approval rate from American adults at 46%, among his best of recent surveys.

“No rebound in decline in black support,” read the survey headline. In its January survey, 57% of blacks approved of Biden, while 41% didn’t. Now the numbers are worse: 56% approve and 43% disapprove.

“The trend in approval by race and ethnicity since July shows a very substantial decline in approval among black adults, with smaller but consistent declines among white and Hispanic respondents,” according to the analysis.

The black vote has been key to Democrats winning federal races for decades, but it showed weakness in the 2020 race, and that has sped up since.

This is Dave Chappelle people. I fully support trans people doing their thing, BUT I do not think all these kids, coming out and saying they are Trans, are for real. If 6 girls are hanging out and suddenly they all come out as Trans, I highly doubt that they all are. The laws of probability say it ain't so. That is what is happening out here and why people are saying that being trans is a fad. There are kids that are Trans, there are kids that don't know where they fall within that spectrum and then you have the kids that just want to be down and get all that acceptance that you get within the LGBTQ+ community. That community gives you support that you don't get in any other community. It's addictive to any kid that doesn't have friends or want to have a lot of them. 

One of those girls was my daughter, and once she broke away from that group (it was 8th grade), and got other friends (she was accepted to a special HS focusing on performing arts, so at the new HS, her friends didn't go with her), she started embracing being a girl again. When she thought she was trans, she wanted us to buy her all kinds of boy clothes, she was talking about getting her breasts cut off, she wanted a shirt that smashed her breasts against her body to make her appear as a boy. She actually cut her hair short. She started re-remembering her past and rewriting her memories....she loved to play in the mud, hated dolls, but in actuality, she hated pants and would scream for at least a half hour if she couldn't have a dress on. She HATED to get dirty. With her dress on...if any mud got on her, the fun was over. She had to get washed up, in another dress and would go back to playing again. Some days, she went through 4 dresses. I hoped our re-direction worked because as much as we loved our daughter and just want her to be healthy and happy, we wanted all the normal everyday girl stuff. We didn't want all the stuff that comes with Trans, ie,...all the crazies that hate on them. Her hair is long, she is wearing clothes that accentuate a little too much of her body now (for my taste), she is talking to her mom and her new girlfriends about the boys that hit on her. 

Obviously, not all girls will have the same experience my daughter had, but I gambled on the fact that my daughter was a follower. I didn't put my foot down on a lot of what she wanted to do, I just said when you get older (18) and still want to do some of those things, then I will see about helping you achieve some of those things. I figured she was 13 and if by 18 she still thought she was "Trans," then she was. I told her, I wasn't getting her one of those shirts that smash her breasts either, but I would support her emotionally. I just didn't want to push her towards her friends even more. If you write me and say, there is nothing wrong with being Trans and try to talk shit, how about you go fuck yourself?! I support Trans, but definitely don't want my kids to have to deal with the issues facing the Trans community. Most parents want their kids to be healthy and not rock the boat when it comes to life. I think I rambled on and on, but I hope some of you get what I'm saying.

Mrs. Doubtfire is problematic.  I am a transgender woman who was 19 years old and yearning to be my authentic self when the movie came out in 1993.  It was revolutionary, campy, and funny, but it is also the embodiment of the lie of "men in dresses for clandestine purposes."  The movie has a valuable place in LGBTQ+ history, but it's not something to use today when discussing gender identity.  Drag is a beautiful and storied performance art and should be celebrated.  The performance of Mrs. Doubtfire is drag, but the plot furthers the same damaging lie being used to ban transgender women and girls in sports, bathrooms, and life in general.  We can both admire the beauty of the art, and realize it is not the appropriate message on this topic.

So this guy is worried about being denied the right to visit his partner in the hospital? As a nurse, I have never once stopped a person from visiting a loved one in the hospital unless the patient specifically told me they did not want visitors at all.  I've never once asked a patient about their sexual orientation because it's irrelevant.  If he wants the right to make healthcare decisions for his partner should his partner become incapacitated, then he can become his partner's Power of Attorney.  It really is that simple. 

A healthcare provider cannot legally deny care to anyone based on race, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, etc. If an LGBT patient requires care that a healthcare provider does not feel competent enough to provide, then they need to refer the LGBT patient to a specialist who can properly care for them.  Perhaps this guy thinks that referrals to another provider is the same as denying care (hint: it is not).  If a provider is heartless enough to tell a patient "Sorry, you're gay.
